awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF: Collaborative Research: An Embodied Intelligent Cognitive Assistant to Enhance Cognitive Performance of Shift Workers
awd_abstract_narration:
The Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier (FW-HTF) is one of 10 new Big Ideas for Future Investment announced by NSF. The FW-HTF cross-directorate program aims to respond to the challenges and opportunities of the changing landscape of jobs and work by supporting convergent research. This award fulfills part of that aim.

This project develops a closed-loop embodied Intelligent Cognitive Assistant (e-ICA) to infer circadian rhythm, alertness, and stress levels and to provide personalized feedback to enhance users' cognitive ability and wellbeing in an unobtrusive and effortless manner. Approximately 20% of the labor force engages in shift work, which often leads to inadequate and poor sleep. Being out of synch with one's natural body clock, or circadian rhythm, can lead to many complications over time, including a higher likelihood for cardiovascular disease, cancer, obesity, and mental health problems. In addition, there can be serious deficits in cognitive performance, with productivity loss and more accidents in the workplace. This research program will design and develop a novel sensor-based e-ICA that can monitor shift workers' circadian rhythms, sleep patterns, and stress levels. The platform will be flexible so that it can be used to study broad populations in addition to shift workers. Given that 70 percent of the population suffers from circadian rhythm disruption, this technology has the potential to impact a wide range of workers and firms. In addition, the anonymized data and information about developed hardware and software will be shared in the community. The technology will impact the needs of a broad cross-section of stakeholders, but will be tested initially with medical residents and other health practitioners who typically work long shift that change every few weeks. Moreover, this project will also allow interdisciplinary cross fertilization between science, engineering, psychology, sleep and circadian biology, and psychiatry.

The investigators explore ways to provide biologically and physiologically attuned support in the areas of cognitive ability, performance, sleep, and well-being based on the inferred individual circadian rhythm and personalized embodied assistance by: a) passively and continuously gathering behavioral and physiological streams through wearable, mobile and remote devices from workers in an effortless manner; b) continuously inferring each person's individual circadian rhythm, alertness, and stress in daily life settings; and c) providing personalized multi-sensory feedback or actionable behavioral suggestions to modulate circadian rhythm, alertness and stress levels with the aim of  enhancing cognitive ability, performance and wellbeing. The investigators will test the efficacy, usability and acceptability of the system both in a series of laboratory studies and in an in-situ work environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project develops a sensor-based Embodied Intelligent Cognitive Assistant (e-ICA) to infer circadian rhythms, alertness, and stress levels, providing personalized feedback to enhance users' cognitive abilities and well-being in an unobtrusive and effortless manner.

The first direction we explored was measuring individual circadian misalignment in the wild to gain a better understanding of the problem. Utilizing a Fitbit Charge 3 and a smartphone app, we collected various physiological and neurobehavioral task data over a 6-week-long study. Data from 24 participants, including shift workers, spanned multiple population groups and covered different performance measures such as vigilant attention and cognitive throughput. Simultaneously, a fitness tracker gathered physiological metrics that might influence these performance measures, including over 900 nights of sleep data and more than 1 million minutes of heart rate and physical activity. Our findings indicated significant variations in sleep-related physiological metrics' influence on each performance measure.

The second direction involved designing contactless Intelligent Cognitive Assistants (ICAs) for respiratory health monitoring, which was particularly relevant during the pandemic. A contactless syndrome sensing framework can assist shift workers and employers in early disease trend identification, shift and break scheduling, social distancing, viral exposure limitation, and data-informed business operations. Such a platform can improve pandemic preparedness and our ability to manage highly infectious respiratory illnesses.

We developed a contactless syndromic surveillance platform that goes beyond traditional influenza-like illness (ILI) surveillance by capturing crowd-level bio-clinical signals related to physical ILI symptoms from hospital waiting areas in a privacy-sensitive manner. The platform includes an edge-computing sensor system, models, and data processing pipelines to monitor crowd behaviors and influenza-related indicators like coughs, predicting daily ILI and laboratory-confirmed influenza caseloads. It utilizes a microphone array and thermal camera, alongside a neural computing engine, to passively and continuously characterize speech and cough sounds, as well as changes in crowd density. A 7-month-long study from December 10, 2018, to July 12, 2019 was conducted at the hospital of a large university which deployed this platform in four public waiting areas. During this period, over 350,000 thermal images and 21 million non-speech audio samples from waiting areas were collected and analyzed. The platform demonstrated a high accuracy in predicting daily patient counts with a Pearson correlation coefficient of 0.95. 

In the third line of work, we developed a fully validated clinical-grade wearable sleep monitoring system that concurrently monitors brain activity, eye movement, muscle activity, cardio-respiratory features, and gross body movements. Typically, such monitoring requires multiple sensors, uncomfortable adhesives, and discrete electronic components in various locations on the head. Existing wearables often compromise either comfort or accuracy in tracking sleep variables. We introduced an all-textile sleep monitoring solution that is practical and comfortable for continuous use, acquiring all relevant sleep signals using comfortable textile sensors placed on the head. 

Collectively, this project explores several new directions in the design and validation of embodied Intelligent Cognitive Assistants (e-ICA).
